July 16, 1953
Dear 8y:
At long last a number of us have had the opportunity to listen to two
of the shows in the ^Jeffersonian Heritage” series* The two tapes
were those which you apparently sent to Dr* Dilworth, Director of Pro¬
gram Planning and Production, almost a year ago* I hadn’t been aware
that they were available here until quits recently*
X think all of us were impressed with ,TThe Living Declaration .** The
show had vitality and humour, as well as dignity and point* I could
perhaps wish that Wishengrad hadn’t made Jefferson quite so aphoristics
but maybe that was the only way significant aspects of his philosophy
could be put across within the half hour limit* The music and the
ballad singer were very nice indeed*
wThe Democrat and the Commissar** by Milton Geiger met a mixed reception
here* Several of us felt that the device of bringing back Jefferson
to testify before a posthumous committee on revolutionary activities
was cumbersome. I personally felt that the case against the Commissar
would in some listeners’ sands be prejudged before the argument began,
partly because the Commissar uses an obviously Russian accent* Other
members- of the Department didn’t feel this way at all and like! both
the voice used and the show as a whole* I think all of us agreed that
the intellectual content is good, with the battle of ideologies being
thrown into sharp and interesting relief.
My reason for writing you now is to ask if we could obtain the other
eleven tapes in the series* Following our current election campaign
which is occupying a good deal of network time, we shall have seven
half-hour periods on Thursdays, 3:00 to 8:30 P«M«, in which a selection
from the Jeffersonian series can be presented. I have read the scripts
and had made tentative decisions about the shows we would like to use*
However, after hearing two of the broadcasts I think we could make a
better selection from actual listening to the entire series.
Would you let me know if we could obtain these tapes fairly soon, since
August 13 would be the date of the first broadcast.
